Justification: It is clear from both options that we have two different scenarios with the same outcome. However, when applying the principles of Utilitarian Ethics and considering the context based on Utility Maximization and Consequence Analysis, it becomes evident that in this specific situation, one option leads to a lesser overall harm compared to the other. While there will be an unfortunate loss of life regardless of which scenario unfolds, we must prioritize which action would minimize the potential harm. In this case, the sudden brake failure has already set in motion a catastrophic event. Swerving and driving through the pedestrian crossing is potentially less risky than continuing ahead and attempting to stop in front of two people who are approaching from directly across the road. Utilitarianism dictates that we aim for maximum overall good or happiness. While neither outcome aligns with this principle, swerving into the other lane may potentially reduce the number of individuals impacted by the sudden loss of control of the self-driving car due to brake failure. In accordance with this principle, I have chosen the option where 2 people, instead of 4, are directly in front of the vehicle at the moment when its brake fails and it swerves into another lane.
